subject: The Hobbit Is Coming Too
event:
This has nothing to do with my own work (well, aside from kindling my love of fantasy in the first place), but as a huge Tolkien fanboy, I can't help but sharing this for the six or seven of you who may not have stumbled on it yet.

<lj-embed id="247"/>

Bilbo!  Gandalf!  Dwarfs!  (No dragons till next picture, though).

Hot damn!  Can't wait!

comments.article: The Lord of the Rings taught us the fantasy literature, A Song of Ice and Fire takes us to the nirvana of it.
Indeed! \o/
It is amazing!I'm glad Peter Jackson directed it, it has the same feel as the LotR Trilogy :)
It doesn't has the same feel as the LOTR trilogy, it looks EXACTLY like LOTR trilogy! I hoped for a bit of originality, the trailer looks quite disappointing...

ONE

WHOLE

YEAR

;_;
And two of my favourite actors in it, too! Can't you get Martin Freeman (John Watson/Bilbo) and Benedict Cumberbatch (Sherlock Homes/Smaug/Necromancer) lined up for GOT? That would be such a treat!

comments.upictitle: Maiden of the Moon: Ahead in time
comments.article: It looks amazing!!:)The introduction to the dwarves was fantastic, Bilbo and Gandalf were so, so great to see, but yup, sigh...no Smaug yet!:p

I've my concerns about this project, for various reasons... but the teaser was very tempting. The swelling music of what I guess is either the main theme or, at least, the theme for the dwarves, is amazingly stirring, right up there with Shore's best themes for the the trilogy. Linda and I just got the complete soundtrack sets for those three films, so we're certainly looking forward to what Shore pulls out his hat for this one.

Appetites definitely whetted.

The Hobbit was a defining book of my childhood. Can't wait to see it, although I'm slightly anxious in case some beloved element gets ruined...

(However, all 13 of The Hobbit's dwarves are not as cool as your one.)

They're making 2 films. Extra stuff that happened at that time frame mentioned in lord of the Rings, but wasn't in the actual Hobbit novel will be included. Which is why we see Galadriel, who wasn't in the Hobbit novel, but met with Gandalf & the White Council @ that time.

Speaking of Tolkien, aside from Hobbit & Lord of the Rings, checkout Silmarillion (as an 'extended' appendeces) & the recent Children of Hurin.
comments.subject: 2 films out of 1 book

comments.article: I don't mind if they add stuff to tie the Hobbit into the main story arch so long as they don't goober the Bilbo/Gollum riddle scene at the underground lake.
comments.subject: Re: 2 films out of 1 book

comments.article:
Well aren’t you « the american Tolkien » anyways???

:¬)

I always thought you Dunk and Egg story ark to be your « The Hobbit » equivalent and ASOIAF your « Lord of the ring » equivalent... So following that chain of thought brings me to believe that once HBO will have gone thru ASOIAF, a few years will pass and they’ll do the Dunk and Egg stuff.
Ooh! Dunc and Egg would make a great feature film! Why wait until ASOIF has run its course on HBO! Let's get a Dunc and Egg movie going now!
They caught my attention with the singing. This could be great.
Shouldn't it be in Dwarvish, though?

There are people on 'The Hobbit''s IMDB page claiming that 'Game of Thrones' should have put an end to "childish nonsense" like the 'The Hobbit'. ASoIaF will always be my favorite book series but I never saw why one can't like both.

So I'm very happy you posted this.
Well of course the Hobbit is childish nonsense - it was written for children!
I love it, and cannot wait! The Hobbit was proabably my first encounter with fantasy.

I must have watched this again and again several times. The dwarves singing still gives me goosebumps every single time.

And Martin Freeman! ♥
comments.subject: Oh my god.

comments.article: Is it me, or does Martin's Bilbo bring to mind Dominic Monaghan's Pippin just a bit?  Ian Holmes played Bilbo with a bit more stature, while Freeman seems to bring a bit more humor. Not complaining! Just commenting!
comments.subject: Re: Oh my god.

Agreed ^

Goosebumps all the way!
I haven't seen it.  Thanks for the post! :)

comments.article:
... and I've read ALL Tolkien's books. Amazing and I can't wait to see the little hobbits and dwarves again. =)

P.S.: But I can't wait to see GoT on HBO next year more than everything else... lol =D
comments.subject: Huge fan also...

comments.article: *Grins* I love that I'm seeing this reposted everywhere!!

comments.upictitle: ☁ come the dawn, we shall see: ❖ (luna) . it was like having friends
comments.article: The trailer is awesome and Thorin & co. look so bad-ass :D

It looks wrong, wrong, wrong.... again. Where to begin? 'The Shire' is meant to be quintessentially English and was Tolkien's 'in memoriam' to all he loved about the fast disappearing English countryside and English rural peoples way of life. This first scene has a ruddy great antipodean gumtree in the frame! All that's missing is a bloody koala (yes, I know it is New Zealand). The hobbits AGAIN look just like humans wearing those hideous slippers (shaped like gorillas feet etc) one receives at Christmas. Real hobbits look nothing like humans! Thorin Oakenshield (like the hobbits)... OMG... no... this can't be happening, is simply dwarf 'eye candy'. Rivendell, again, looks like a child's cheap, plastic Sylvanian elfland set. And the ugly stone statues... everywhere... again! What's with the bloody statues Peter? Is it some kind of repressed RC 'Virgin Mary' hangup? Elves do not make STONE statues, stone being the antipathy of what elves are: mercurial, will-o-the-wisps, lovers of trees and the lords of LIVING nature, (the greenman peering through the trees, (the genesis of Fa & Lok in Golding's 'The Inheritors') far stronger and dreadful than DEAD stone. Stone is for the dwarves. Statues are human creations, images of ourselves to glorify & worship ourselves. Elves do not worship elves, they worship the earth. Sigh, I'll go to this movie, I'll buy the popcorn and I'll enjoy the special effects, I have no doubt, but it's not Tolkien's Hobbit, it's Peter Jackson's New Zealand Hobbit. The glimpse of 'Hobbiton-on-the-Green' looks like an Australian sheep farm... Never England. Enjoyable I'm sure, in its way.. G'day Elrond. The English need to make a version of 'The Hobbit' and take back their heritage. Then it might look something akin to Tolkien's world. (I'm not English myself).
comments.subject: Not A Hobbit

comments.article: CAN'T...WAIT!!!

Obviously, Peter Jack son did NOT rid himself of his latent
sadistic tendancies with LOTR ---- a YEAR until Part One!! And the ANOTHER YEAR until Part Two!!!*bangs head against wall*
That said, I do hope we get the trolls ....
That trailer looks so good and we still have to wait a whole year!

I really don't understand the constant bashing of Jacksons LOTR movies. They were great movies, thought different from the books. The movies are his vision of middle earth, and if they are different than mine that's ok. Just the fact that it made millions more people aware of a great story makes them worth it. People in my family and a bunch of friends who never would have read these books now love LOTR, which is amazing. Now my 7 year old son can't wait to see The Hobbit in the theater, and I can't wait to bring him. He has already said when he gets a little older he will read the books, so there will be a new generation of fans in my family. Jackson's movies are a positive to the Tolkien legacy not a negative.
